factoids.title: Conway's Life Origins
factoids.text: Conway's Game of Life was invented by John Conway in 1970 as a zero-player game that demonstrates cellular automaton behavior.

factoids.title: Simple Rules, Complex Behavior
factoids.text: Despite having only 4 simple rules, Conway's Life can create incredibly complex patterns including gliders, oscillators, and even universal computers.

factoids.title: The Birth Rule
factoids.text: A dead cell becomes alive if it has exactly 3 living neighbors - this mimics biological reproduction requiring multiple 'parents'.

factoids.title: Survival Conditions
factoids.text: Living cells survive only with 2 or 3 neighbors - too few (loneliness) or too many (overcrowding) causes death.

factoids.title: Glider Discovery
factoids.text: The glider, a 5-cell pattern that moves diagonally, was one of the first moving patterns discovered and became an icon of cellular automata.

factoids.title: Universal Computation
factoids.text: Conway's Life is Turing complete - it can simulate any computer program given enough space and time.

factoids.title: The R-pentomino
factoids.text: This 5-cell pattern takes 1103 generations to stabilize, producing 6 gliders, 8 blocks, 4 blinkers, 1 beehive, and 1 loaf.

factoids.title: Still Life Patterns
factoids.text: Some patterns never change once formed - the simplest is the 'block' (2×2 square), followed by the 'beehive' and 'loaf'.

factoids.title: Oscillators
factoids.text: Patterns that repeat their shape after a fixed number of generations - the 'blinker' has period 2, the 'toad' has period 2.

factoids.title: Spaceships
factoids.text: Self-replicating patterns that move across the grid - gliders move at c/4 speed (1 cell every 4 generations diagonally).

factoids.title: Garden of Eden
factoids.text: Some configurations can never be reached from any previous generation - they can only exist as initial conditions.

factoids.title: Methuselahs
factoids.text: Small patterns that take a very long time to stabilize - the 'acorn' pattern takes 5206 generations to settle.

factoids.title: Gosper Glider Gun
factoids.text: Discovered by Bill Gosper in 1970, this was the first known pattern that creates an infinite number of gliders.

factoids.title: Population Dynamics
factoids.text: Random initial configurations typically stabilize around 3-5% living cells, showing emergence of order from chaos.

factoids.title: Edge Effects
factoids.text: Finite grids create edge effects that can dramatically change pattern behavior compared to infinite grids.

factoids.title: Generation 0
factoids.text: The initial configuration is called 'Generation 0' - every subsequent step increases the generation count by 1.

factoids.title: Conway's Conjecture
factoids.text: Conway originally conjectured that no finite pattern could grow without bound - this was disproven by the glider gun.

factoids.title: Density Classification
factoids.text: Random grids with ~37% initial density tend to produce the most interesting long-term dynamics.

factoids.title: Reflection Symmetry
factoids.text: Many stable patterns exhibit reflection symmetry, suggesting deep mathematical relationships in cellular automata.

factoids.title: Speed Limits
factoids.text: Information cannot travel faster than 1 cell per generation (speed of light 'c'), limiting spaceship velocities.

factoids.title: Binary Counting
factoids.text: Complex Life patterns can implement binary counters, demonstrating computational capabilities within the cellular automaton.

factoids.title: The Conway Notation
factoids.text: Patterns are often described using 'b' for birth and 's' for survive conditions - Life is B3/S23.

factoids.title: Periodic Patterns
factoids.text: Oscillators can have any period ≥2 - periods 1 (still life), 2, 3, 4, 5, 6... up to arbitrarily large periods exist.

factoids.title: Conway's Legacy
factoids.text: John Conway (1937-2020) created this 'game' as a mathematical exploration that became foundational to complexity science.

factoids.title: Cellular Neighborhoods
factoids.text: Each cell considers its 8 neighbors (Moore neighborhood) - this simple local rule creates global patterns.

factoids.title: Zero-Player Game
factoids.text: Life requires no human input after the initial setup - the rules alone determine all future evolution.

factoids.title: Mathematical Beauty
factoids.text: Life demonstrates how simple deterministic rules can create patterns of stunning complexity and unexpected beauty.

factoids.title: Emergence Principle
factoids.text: Complex behaviors emerge from simple interactions - a key principle in complexity theory and systems science.

factoids.title: Digital Physics
factoids.text: Some theorists suggest our universe might operate like a cellular automaton, making Life a model of reality itself.

factoids.title: Pattern Libraries
factoids.text: Thousands of Life patterns have been catalogued, from tiny oscillators to massive computational structures.
